Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery lekane; glaze fird red-brown; interior: part of an incised spoked rosette; exterior: black-figure animal frieze (only hind legs and one front hoof of deer or goat remaining), to left; incised blob and spoked rosettes as filling ornament; below, two bands above rays.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Athens 931
Curator's comments: The sherd belongs to the same vessel as British Museum 1886,0401.1043.a, 1886,0401.1043.b and either 1886,0401.1008 or1886, 0401.1054. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.994. For the shape, see British Museum 1861,0425.46. C.W. Neeft (personal communication) considers that the lekane is the work of the Painter of Athens 931.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.7.2)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 91, no. A120)
Boardman 1998 / Early Greek Vase Painting (11th - 6th Centuries BC) (p. 198, fig. 395)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 35)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.115) (Phase 1)
